messages.subject: Question about a Book
messages.msgSnippet: Guys & Gals, Got a question for you all. I just picked up a book today Tanto by SUZUKI Yoshisada. I am curious as to if these books were signed by the
messages.messageBody:
Guys & Gals,

Got a question for you all. I just picked up a book
today "Tanto" by SUZUKI Yoshisada. I am curious as to
if these books were signed by the author. Do any of
you have this book and does the inside cover look
anything like the image below? If not can any of you
read what is written on the inside cover of this one?
Thanks for your help.

http://tinyurl.com/evwi

Bob R

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: been a little quite
messages.msgSnippet: and while I m on a roll, we all enjoyed Ron s excellent tanto koshirae when we were discussing the small tanto last week, but I am unsure if I saw an answer to
messages.messageBody:
and while I'm on a roll, we all enjoyed Ron's excellent tanto koshirae
when we were discussing the small tanto last week, but I am unsure if I
saw an answer to my original question.

Were these very little blades common in any particular period. It was
suggested that they may have been made for women's wedding presents or
some such thing, and I think it was suggested that blades offered to
women as presents was a Meiji or there abouts practice.

I would have thought a small blade would be easy to conceal and
therefore perfect for any clandestin action. I am wondering if these
very small blades ( 15 cm or there abouts ) were common to any
particular era. I wouldn't have thought they would be useful as
yorio-doshi as they would be too short, though they all seem to be quite
wide so I thought they may have not been Koto. So I guess that leaves
Shinto and on.

Any thoughts on this.

Cheers all

Richard

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: been a little quite
messages.msgSnippet: Jim et al- While I dig this style of Koshirae very much, I can t say I know all I would like to about them. Toppei I believe refers to the shape of the kashira
messages.messageBody:
Jim et al-
While I dig this style of Koshirae very much, I can't say I
know all I would like to about them. Toppei I believe refers to the
shape of the kashira and kojiri IE; tapering. I agree with all that
Jim has said, I believe these were popular at the tail end of the Edo
period when Western weapons and tactics were being fervently studied
by the Japanese.
This style of koshirae could be used with hakama or European
trousers, hence the swivel often seen. The swivelling "kurikata"
allowed the sword to be thrust thru the Obi or slung "backward" in
western fashion when dressed in pants.
The gunto koshirae is an extension of this idea and one can
see how many different ways were invented to allow quick conversion
from saber to uchigatana...
More often than not these are of superior workmanship. My
belief is that the new officers of the newly formed rifle or
artillery units went for this style and most of them with the money
to get a special set up like this were likely sons of the Bakufu.
There is one memorable example of this style which is decidedly
common, showing rough simple work suitable more for a foot soldier
than an officer; That would be Saigo Takamoris' shuzaya toppei
goshirae which carried a gimei Muramasa blade.
I think this little tanto exhibits all the features of a
quality koshirae in this style. There is one more feature not yet
mentioned and that is that Toppei koshirae typically feature iron
fittings with silver inlay (sometimes gold).
That really is all I know (or have been taught). Thirsting for more,
Tom

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: been a little quite
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, Koshirae with that kind of spring clip are usually (maybe always) fitted with a ring rather than a traditional kurikata.  I don t know what the difference
messages.messageBody:
Ron,
Koshirae with that kind of spring clip are usually (maybe always) fitted with a ring rather than a traditional kurikata. I don't know what the difference in use was, but there probably was a practical reason. I don't have a firm understanding of toppei koshirae, but at least some of these examples with the external spring clip were apparently made for wear with Western-style clothing. Some toppei koshirae without a spring clip still have a ring-swivel fitting instead of a kurikata. Others have a fixed or swivel ring mounted on the "edge" rather than the side of the saya. I think that the sageo used was more like a string rather than a flat braid. I suspect that they were worn at a different angle to the body and possibly there was a greater risk of the sword falling out of the saya, hence the clip. I don't know much about them. Tom, any ideas?

Etched soft metal isn't a very common technique. Good lacquer and an interesting wrap, too. It would fit right in the Edo no Tanto Koshirae picture book.
Jim



Jim:

Thanks for the compliment!

Soft metal fittings that were etched.
It has a ring, not kurikata. (was this used for a different purpose?)

Thanks very much,
Ron P.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: been a little quite
messages.msgSnippet: Tom: Thanks for the compliment on the sword! I should have brought it to NY (NTHK shinsa) last year. (I had tsuba submitted because I didn t know I was
messages.messageBody:
Tom:

Thanks for the compliment on the sword!

I should have brought it to NY (NTHK shinsa) last year. (I had tsuba
submitted because I didn't know I was actually going to make it
until the last minute)

It is interesting the way they used the leather as a spring. The
lock still works well. Nice simple design.

I think if I was starting in nihonto all over again I would
specialize in tanto...so many wonderful examples of blades/koshirae.

Ron P.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, tom helm <junkmail@t...> wrote:
> Rich-
> Probably talking outta my hat as usual but I think we should
> remember that these were small people, who needed to carry a
variety
> of blades for as many uses. Simply because the blade is diminutive
> doesn't connect it to a woman, the koshirae would be the clue for
> deducing who used it.
> Mamorigatana as a wedding gift was part of samurai culture
> that enjoyed a brief fad in the Meiji period because the Emperor
> adopted it (the influence of his evil samurai handlers...)
> My father-in-law has one for my wife but because it is such
a
> sweet sword he has yet to give it to her, we've been married six
> years!?!
> Ron, that is one sweet tanto you have there. Has it been
> papered? That koshirae deserves to be published. Would love to see
> that in person some day...
> -t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] been a little quite
messages.msgSnippet: Rich- Probably talking outta my hat as usual but I think we should remember that these were small people, who needed to carry a variety of blades for as many
messages.messageBody:
Rich-
Probably talking outta my hat as usual but I think we should
remember that these were small people, who needed to carry a variety
of blades for as many uses. Simply because the blade is diminutive
doesn't connect it to a woman, the koshirae would be the clue for
deducing who used it.
Mamorigatana as a wedding gift was part of samurai culture
that enjoyed a brief fad in the Meiji period because the Emperor
adopted it (the influence of his evil samurai handlers...)
My father-in-law has one for my wife but because it is such a
sweet sword he has yet to give it to her, we've been married six
years!?!
Ron, that is one sweet tanto you have there. Has it been
papered? That koshirae deserves to be published. Would love to see
that in person some day...
-t

messages.subject: been a little quite
messages.msgSnippet: Greetings all, I thought I would run this by the group since its been a bit ( read lot ) quite out there. A mate and I were talkin swod tok the other night and
messages.messageBody:
Greetings all, I thought I would run this by the group since its been a
bit ( read lot ) quite out there. A mate and I were talkin swod tok the
other night and we were discussing tanto. He mentioned and sent pics of
a very small blade that measures app 22cm in total length. As it turns
out, I have one almost identical in size. Mine, as is his is also quite
thick, both about 7 or 8 mm at the munemachi, very much like a
yorio-doshi only far too short.

Paul mentioned that he was told his was made as a gift for the wife of a
samurai as a wedding present. He believes his to be mid/late edo and
traditionally made. MIne is out of polish and hard to see hada or hamon,
nie, nioi etc.. but the rest of it looks pretty similar.

here is a link to the two tanto Tantos <www.whiz.com.au/richard/tantos.jpg>

I believe blades were common gifts for samurai wife's and I would expect
them to be smaller than usual but 22 cm is pretty small and more like a
child's size, though I guess weilded properly, could inflict just as
much damage as a 30cm tanto.

looking forward to all opinions.

cheers

Rich


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
